result.title: Objective
result.description: To increase the resilience and reduce vulnerability of local, critical economic infrastructure in the northern mountains areas of Vietnam to the adverse impacts of climate change and to create a policy framework conducive to promoting resilient northern mountains zone development.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: # of vulnerability maps presented and disseminated to % of Northern Mountain provinces.

baseline.comment: n/a – at project outset there is no vulnerability maps to disseminate

target.comment: Detailed vulnerability maps for at least two northern mountainous provinces (a map for each province), with evidence that these have been presented and disseminated to at least 50% of Northern Mountain Provinces.

actual.comment: On track. Fifty percent completed. Vulnerability assessment results are nearly completed. The CPMU mobilized a firm and an international climate change expert in Quarter III 2014. An international climate change expert supported a national team to finalize the vulnerability assessment methodology introduced at the inception workshop (November 2013). A number of meetings with different institutions/ individuals were held, including a vulnerability assessment methodology consultation workshop in October 2014 to help finalize the methodology. After data collection and analysis, the consultant has submitted a complete database set and vulnerability assessment report to CPMU. Results were shared with Government stakeholders from 15 Northern mountain provinces and downscaled to two piloting provinces namely Backan and Sonla. This work will be further supported by the development of landslide and flashflood risk maps for the whole region and two provinces and will be completed in 2015. They are expected to provide visual vulnerability results based on different scenarios (AR-5, IPCC). This is a valuable opportunity for GoV to place in the public domain the extent of, and the spatial allocation of the likely public expenditures needed for resilience measures, and considered a key impact, as the baseline does not provide information on spatial variability of risk and vulnerability. As such, decision makers can recognize the vulnerabilities of their own provinces in comparison with other provinces. They may also learn how to cope with climate change from the provinces with same situation but higher coping capacities (less vulnerability). On the other hand and more importantly, they can use these maps as inputs for their rural infrastructure-related decisions, especially medium and long-termed planning. Achievements will be shared with Northern mountain provinces through relevant trainings at the end of 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: % of public expenditure directed towards the protection of rural infrastructure following the project guidance on climate resilient infrastructure.

baseline.comment: 0 funds invested

target.comment: On 05 rural infrastructure projects, at least 5% additional public finance invested in infrastructure resilience, over and above SRID pilot demonstration.

actual.comment:
On track. The vulnerability index and the hazard impact assessments will assist in the calculation of climate adaptation costs for rural infrastructure projects. The economic analysis team is working on this matter to introduce the formula and a number of case studies as examples. However, it is difficult to apply this formula under the SRIDP sub-projects because they have finished the sub-project screening, which requires economic analysis to be provided in advance. Hence the independent Midterm review team who were mobilized by UNDP-GEF in April suggest that CPMU, UNDP and MARD should discuss how to utilize this result in future projects. This issue might be brought to a PSC meeting which will be organized in late 2015 as expected. Currently, reviewing of the existing data/ situations/ documents/ etc. has finished and the second phase to deliver recommendations is well underway.
The following reports approved/ submitted: (i) policy (04 reports): Overview on existing policy and strategy related to rural infrastructure, Report of International good practices in policy and practice for climate resilient rural infrastructure, A thematic report on strengthening the resilience of rural infrastructure to climate change at international level, with focus on: (- Rural road infrastructure;- Rural water supply and irrigation; and, - River protection embankment); Thematic report on development of SEDP and agricultural and transportation sector plans in relation to rural infrastructure of the Northern mountain region; and (ii) economic analysis (02) cost-benefit analysis for climate proofing rural infrastructure projects, Report on Measures to quantify economic damages caused by CC on rural infrastructure in Northern mountain area; (iii) rural infrastructure engineering (5): The report on good international practice of engineering resilience in the context of rural roads, irrigation network and river embankments; Root cause analysis for losses and damages to the rural road infrastructure; Root cause analysis for loses and damages to the irrigation and river embankment infrastructure; The report on rural infrastructure vulnerability assessment to climate change for the Northern mountain provinces in Vietnam; Recommendations on integration of climate change adaptation into rural road investments; and Recommendations on integration of climate change into irrigation and embankment investments; (iv) vulnerability assessment report; (v) capacity strengthening: Report on climate change impacts on poverty reduction and socio-economic development in the northern mountain provinces; Report on the need of capacity strengthening on CC adaptation of northern mountain provinces and Report on the capacity strengthening plan on CC adaptation of northern mountain provinces.
A series of technical and progress meetings/ consultations/ field trips were held to improve the quality of the outputs and fasten the project progress with participation of various partners at different levels (community, district, province and central levels). Consulted institutions include (i) MARD - Directorate of Water Resources, Department of Construction Management, Department of Planning, Department of Science, Technology and Environment, Institute of Policy and Strategy for Agriculture and Rural Development, Institute of Water Resources Planning; Disaster Management Center; New Rural Area Program Committee, Department of Dyke and Flood Protection, Vietnam Academy of Water Resources; National Institute of Agriculture Planning and Projection, Water Resources University, Institute of Water Resources Planning; (ii) MONRE - Institute of Hydrology, Meteorology and Climate change; Vietnam Institute of Geosciences and Mineral Resources, Institute of Geology; and Vietnam Department of Survey and Mapping; (iii) MOT - University of Transport; Transport Development and Strategy Institute; (iv) 15 project provinces and communes.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Climate Change Adaptation integrated into rural infrastructure (i.e. transport, irrigation, construction and water supply) strategies, policies, plans and regulations.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: # of Technical papers providing guidance on mainstreaming climate change into sectorial planning related to rural infrastructure in northern areas.

baseline.comment: n/a – there has not been a guidance paper at project outset.

target.comment: A Technical Guidance Paper on mainstreaming climate change into provincial rural infrastructure planning prepared by the project and circulated by MARD.

actual.comment:
On track. The project successfully completed a comprehensive review of relevant policies that included a series of stakeholder consultations. Key findings include that most of MARD policies/ strategies do not take climate change into consideration and are not detailed enough for application. The need to employ pro-poor and no-regret approaches for resilience building were also clearly highlighted. The New Rural Development Program, Sustainable Poverty Reduction Program and provincial socio-economic development planning processes were particularly identified as priorities for further analysis and engagement by the project.
A policy consultation workshop at Thai Nguyen province on 9 September 2014 was able to solicit inputs from 11 departments/ institutes from MARD and MONRE and 14 DARDs. The meeting further highlighted the continued interest in learning from international experience in bio-engineering/ low-cost measures to support resilience.
A comprehensive review of current rural infrastructure planning, implementation and maintenance and field missions to discuss with key focal points, Government officials and community representatives highlighted a number of issues regarding low-cost measures including bio-engineering measures. The assessment included review of experience from 27 countries from the Netherlands to Laos with legal frameworks, codes and policies and implementation methods for introducing low-cost and bio-engineering options.
Analysis of the most recent climate change projections for Viet Nam and their potential impacts in the focus regions was also a key element of this work. With regards to the analysis of key hazards for the region, potential increases in intense and concentrated rainfall, and associated landslide risk, were highlighted as an issue in climate change projections that was particularly of concern with regards to rural infrastructure. Other factors impacting current resilience of infrastructure included poor designs, using unqualified materials, applying unsuitable technical solutions during construction process and O&M. The review also recognized the clear need to integrate climate change into existing relevant codes and standards, especially C6-77 regarding calculation of meteorological features of irrigation structures which has been issued since 1970s. This implies that the vulnerability mapping under the project should take into account of above-mentioned climate disasters.
Key steps were also taken into initiating a review of current economic analysis practices and in starting to look at the economic consequences of climate change (losses). This work is likely to bolster the success of the project in suggesting appropriate methods, tools and procedures for climate proofing investment decision-making in the NMP. At a higher (Provincial) level, it is likely that a key tool for climate change adaptation investment guidance will continue to be the application of the MCA Multi Criteria Analysis method, as illustrated by the application of UNDP Teams integrated VA and Hazard models (which adopt an integrated format, in common with ICEM CAM methodology). As an example, work on the VA component has identified marked differences in Vulnerability between NMP provinces and ongoing work on Flood and Landslide Hazard risk is expected to further identify differences between provinces, which can assist to pinpoint the urgency and extent of CCA interventions (investments).
(To continue in General Comment box on Basic Data tab)

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: # of Manual on mainstreaming climate change into the design of rural infrastructure projects.

baseline.comment: n/a - at the project outset, there has not been a manual to guide mainstreaming of CC into the design of rural infrastructure projects.

target.comment: 02 manuals on mainstreaming climate change into the design of rural infrastructure projects (01 for rural roads and irrigation, and 01 for embankment) prepared by the project (taking into consideration of results of the demonstration projects) and circulated by MARD.

actual.comment: On track. The review phase indicates that although MARD has launched a lot of rural infrastructure projects, applied technical codes/ standards regarding rural roads come from MOT. However, Ministry of Transport has not really touched climate change adaptation in their projects/ planning/ codes/ standards. Hence, there is a need to improve existing code/ standards to consider climate resilience for these infrastructures. The review phase also revealed that it is not at all simple to insert project recommendations into existing codes/ standards of MOT since it is not only a long process but also requires inter-ministerial discussions. Despite such difficulties, some findings and recommendations mentioned in the report "Root cause analysis for loses and damages to the rural road infrastructure" have contributed to the draft manual of rural transport roads of the MOT. The contents inserted into the draft consist of (i) climate change impacts on rural roads; (ii) the importance of construction of drain structures; (iii) a number of feasible technical measures that can be applied; (iv) a number of pavements that can increase the resilience to climate change and (v) the importance of bio-engineering measures for slope protection. This can be seen as a great effort of the project already. Besides, the project has had similar contribution to the upgrading of two technical standards of MARD namely slope concrete standard and dam safety standard. The meetings with the two standard improvement teams have shown their high consensus in increasing the thickness of slope slabs to decrease the oxidation as consequence of extreme weather. Project recommendations have been appreciated and captured in the reports of standard improvement teams. Regarding the indicator of this outcome, to ensure the quality of UNDP's support to MARD, the MidTerm Review consultants suggest to change the indicator as "# of Manual on mainstreaming climate change into the design of rural infrastructure projects". Presently, consultant teams are working together to develop the manuals which are very coherent with each other (vulnerability index and Costs/Benefits calculation for instance). The methodologies to develop these manuals have been discussed with CPMU and UNDP based on the orientations/ expectations of the participants in the policy consultation workshop dated 29th May 2015. The expectations are mainly (i) a policy roadmap for MARD to adapt to climate change including possible technical standards; (ii) climate hazard risk maps and provincial planning based on these maps; (iii) low-cost and bio-engineering measures and (iv) related trainings. It is expected that first drafts of the manuals can be available in Quarter III/2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: # of water resources standards and codes are informed to meet the requirements for climate resilience.

baseline.comment: n/a – there has not been any revision of water resources standards or codes.

target.comment: By the end of the project at least 01 set of water resources standards informed by the project guidance.

actual.comment: On track with good progress. After a lot of consultations with both central and provincial levels showed that they all are very interested in upgrading codes/ standards or build a new set of standards to enable the application of new technologies or low-cost measures. Lack of these standards results in very time-consuming procedures in approval of bio-engineering interventions because MARD has no legal base for reference. This is also why demonstration subprojects managed by ADB have encountered a lot of difficulties regarding lack of related standards for their designs. Beside contributing to upgrading existing standards as mentioned in Indicator 2 of this Outcome, the project is (i) providing detailed recommendations on a key technical standard of Vietnam in irrigation named C6-77 regarding calculation of meteorological features of irrigation structures and (ii) developing rural infrastructure engineering manuals which will provide s technical guidance for MARD to develop their own low-cost solution guidelines and then standards in near future. Consultations were held with the technical staff of the Department of Science, Technology and Environment (MARD) and Institute of Meteorology, Hydrology, Environment and Climate Change (MONRE) on updating C6-77. MARD is considering updating this standard in coming years, and the project will provide some initial support to MARD regarding this standard as their expectations. In 2015, the project expects to deliver specific recommendations by QIII and then consult again with MARD and related agencies regarding these recommendations. UNDP has also been working closely with the ADB component to help create a link between target sites and Government policy development regarding low-cost measures. Based on the designs, site visits, experience and lessons learnt and together with other feasible lessons, the technical team will develop detailed technical guidance documents of low-cost measures.

target.comment: N/A

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Enhanced capacity to adapt/climate-proof rural infrastructure investments and provincial/local area planning.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Coverage of Climate risks and vulnerability assessment.

baseline.comment: There has not been any climate vulnerability assessment implemented for rural infrastructure in Northern mountain provinces.

target.comment: A climate risks and vulnerability assessment for rural infrastructure done for all 15 northern provinces.

actual.comment: On track. As reported above, the assessment will cover 15 project provinces including Dien Bien, Lai Chau, Son la, Hoa Binh, Vinh Phuc, Phu Tho, Bac Giang, Bac Kan, Yen Bai, Lao Cai, Lang Son, Cao Bang, Thai Nguyen, Tuyen Quang and Ha Giang, then downscaled to Son La and Backan. After the vulnerability assessment methodology approved, the contractor sent their teams to all provinces and then all districts of two demonstration provinces as named above Son La and Backan to collect secondary data and interviews for missing data (O&M data). The types of structures under the assessment consist of (i) rural roads; (ii) river embankments; (iii) weirs; (iv) reservoirs and (v) main canals that are classified as categorical and continuous. The process tracks the following indicators: age of works, number of communes cut off from main road per year, past damages, number of secondary structures on road, material of road/ embankment, O&M, ratio of poor households, proportion of minorities, proportion of working age population, community contribution to infrastructure, number of site inspection, type of construction codes followed, number of times of damages, number of reservoirs stopped from functioning. Weightings are also laid for each kind of these indicators.Results show a picture of Son La, Backan and Ha Giang as the most vulnerable province in terms of risk. These results will be further deepened with specific recommendations provided by the project in the remaining time of the year. The next step will be to integrate these maps with future climate change projects.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: # of rural infrastructure investment plans guided as results of climate risks and vulnerability assessment, regarding mainstreaming of CC.

baseline.comment: n/a – there has not been any rural infrastructure plan that is developed based on climate risk and vulnerability assessment.

target.comment: At least two (02) provincial plans/strategy per target province (Son La and Bac Kan) guided as results of the project climate risks and vulnerability assessments, regarding mainstreaming of CC.

actual.comment:
"Major planning decisions being modified due to vulnerability maps (in 2 target provinces)" indicator should be changed into "# of rural infrastructure investment plans guided as results of climate risks and vulnerability assessment, regarding mainstreaming of CC", which reflects better the influences of the project on the provinces because the project can only suggest the provinces to use the outputs. To date, climate risk and vulnerability maps have been provided to all target provinces for use in planning. Two PPCs (Backan and Sonla) have expressed their willingness to apply project recommendations into their investment plans. A provincial strategy expert who is being under recruitment of CPMU will take this work forward.
A team of provincial strategy development is under recruitment of CPMU. They will be mobilized in August as expected for review of existing provincial action plans and then recommend appropriate adjustments. If mapping packages can happen as expected, this team can take use of the maps for their recommendation report. Generally speaking, this activity is on track with a risk as indicated above.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
Level of capacity of provincial leaders to climate-proof rural infrastructure investment and planning enhanced
% of technical personnel having ability to apply risk and vulnerability assessment tools and methods for rural infrastructure development planning purposes

baseline.comment:
At the project outset, evaluated scores of management personnel in the 15 Northern provinces are as follows:
Institutional capacity on climate change adaptation (CCA) = 1.43/5
Organizational and planning capacity on CCA =1.71/5; and
Technical capacity on CCA = 1.78/5
Risk and vulnerability assessment tools and methods for rural infrastructure development planning is not yet available in Vietnam.

target.comment:
By the end of the project, capacity of provincial decision makers (DARD, DPI, DOT, DONRE) to climate-proof rural infrastructure investment and planning in the 15 northern mountainous provinces is at least (40%) higher than the project baseline;
Up to 120 technical personnel from the 15 Northern provinces trained in CCA related issues and at least 50% of them having technical capability in applying climate risks and vulnerability assessment tools and methods for rural infrastructure development planning purposes.

actual.comment: On track with delay. This activity has started slower than the others because trainings had to be developed based on project results. Mobilized in Quarter II/2014, the capacity strengthening expert completed a capacity strengthening assessment focusing on institutional, organizational and technical capacities. These results reflect the baseline of the project. The assessment indicated a high level of demand for in improving the local capacity for climate change adaptation. In response to this, the project has decided to increase the number of training events by 40% Provincial stakeholders had a chance ot contribute to the design of the training programme through two consultation meetings. Trainings will focus on 04 topics namely (i) Policy for climate change resilience for senior provincial officials; (ii) Vulnerability assessment as a tool to increase climate change resilience for technical officers; (iii) Integrating climate change resilience into annual planning and prioritization and (iv) Training skills about climate change adaptation for provincial officials. As such, the details on vulnerability assessment tools and methods for rural infrastructure planning will bee transferred in (ii) and (iii). Target trainees include leaders and technical/ planning staff of 04 relevant provincial departments including Department of Agriculture and Rural Development, Department of Transport, Department of Natural Resources and Environment and Department of Planning and Investment from 15 beneficiary provinces. Trainers will be project experts or outsourced from professional agencies such as Institute of Meteorology, Hydrology and Climate Change. There will be a total of 12 classes for 04 mentioned topics targeted to senior and technical level staff. Around 120 government personnel ware expected to be trained.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Effective climate-resilience measures mainstreamed into rural infrastructure programs.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: The approaches developedâ€”including promising modifications, alternatives, and lessons learnedâ€”will be utilized by MARD rural infrastructure investments as standard practice in 100% of new ADB-financed projects by month 36.

baseline.comment: MARD has mainstreamed low cost climate measures for cross drainage structures by the use of drifts but not other measures.

target.comment: 1. Documentation identifying low cost climate proofing suitable for rural infrastructure in northern Viet Nam completed

baseline.comment: There are no demonstrations of appropriate climate resilience techniques for rural infrastructure.

target.comment: 2. Demonstrations are successfully completed on four SRIDP subprojects by month 24.
3. Training carried out for 60 (â‰¥40% female) DARD staff from the 15 project provinces by month 34.
4. Recommendations completed and issued to the relevant institutions by month 34
5. Assessments for strengthening the climate resilience of the communities near the four subproject areas completed by month 30

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Lessons learnt and best practices from Outcomes 1, 2 and 3 are disseminated to stakeholders and development partners

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: # of Project lessons and best practices captured, classified and evaluated;

baseline.comment: No project lessons learnt published by the project at the project outset

target.comment:
At least 08 articles/video clips/leaflets published by the end of the project
At least two (02) peer technical papers reviewed by the end of the project to facilitate professional discussion and advocacy

actual.comment: On track. Most of communication products will come at the final phase of the project to introduce project outputs. However, after the review phase, there were some articles published on websites/ magazines to (i) emphasize the necessity of climate adaptation in existing legal documents or (ii) draw attention to a number of technical adaptation measures. Articles published include: (1) “Integration of climate adaptation into relevant policy regarding water resources structures in Northern mountain region” published in Water Resources magazine in April 2015; (2) An article on the vulnerability assessment methodology workshop was published on 27th October 2014 by the Vietnam Science and Technology magazine (3) “Non-structural measures to protect slop at Northern Mountain region” by Mr. Hoang Tuan, Vice Director of Department of Construction Management (MARD) was published in on the VNCOLD website (Vietnam National Committee of Large Dams and Water Resources Development). Additional articles are under draft. The CPMU is recruiting a communication specialist who will help to capture project lessons, share experience through articles or videos.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Level of CCA knowledge and experiences documented and disseminated within Vietnam, in the Asian region and beyond

baseline.comment: 0 contributions.

target.comment: At least 04 contributions by the end of the project (ALM records/ platforms)

actual.comment: Started. Project deliverables will be documented and shared within Vietnam, in the Asian region and beyond. It is expected that there will be low-cost measures documented to become manuals. Besides, future projects may also learn from both negative and positive lessons gained through a project management report. All of these products are under development and can be available in next year, 2016.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1) Quality of data collection and policy-oriented research and law submissions by the Viet Nam Lawyers' Association (VLA) and civil society organizations (CSOs) to the Government and National Assembly (1 - very poor; 2 - relatively good; 3 - good; 4 - very good). 2) Number of the poor and disadvantaged in the target regions being aware of their rights and benefiting from access to the VLA Legal Consultancy Centers (LCCs) and legal aid service. 3) Availability of mechanism for partnership and collaboration between VLA and other social organizations/CSOs to address social justice.

baseline.comment: 1) 1-very poor. Very limited capacity of the Viet Nam Lawyers' Association (VLA) in policy submission and legislation due to lack of a systematic data collection and analysis. Limited capacity of the VLA in empirical research and data collection to support its policy and law-reform recommendations. 2) Small number of people assisted by the VLA's Legal Consultancy Centers due to the constrained resource and the lack of innovation in their outreach program and service delivery method. 3) Mechanism for partnership and collaboration between the VLA and local NGOs, CSOs on addressing social injustice does not exist.

target.comment: 1) 2-relatively good quality of data collection by VLA and CSOs through development of a software for recording and compiling legal opinions and training on policy advocacy for VLA members at different levels, with thematic focus on the rights of pre-trial detainees, the right to referendum and due process in administrative litigation. 2) At least 7000 beneficiaries assisted by the VLA through the introduction of Legal Empowerment for the Poor approach in the VLA's outreach to the poor and vulnerable groups. 3) A model for collaborative work in combating injustice between a VLA's Legal Consultancy Center and local NGOs is piloted for future duplication.

actual.comment: 1) 3-good. A very strong mechanism for quality data collection resulted in semi-annual submission to National Assembly on law reform proposals to the best interests of the most vulnerable groups. Completion of two research studies on pretrial detainees and administrative litigations respectively with policy recommendations sent to the Drafting Committees for amending the Law on Administrative Litigation and the Law on Investigation and Pre-trial Detention. 2) 7,073 poor people benefited by VLA legal aid through Legal Empowerment for the Poor approach 3) A model of VLA-local NGO partnership is experimented, which contributes to strengthen the networking and policy coalition between legal professional organizations and civil society organizations in legislation support, for example, policy inputs to drafting a Law on Referendum in Vietnam.

target.comment: 1) 4-very good quality of data collection and law submissions though continuous support to VLA, with focus on the development of a new instrument for citizen's voice on the administration of justice (entitled "Justice Index in 2015". 2) At least 8,000 poor people benefited by VLA legal aid 3) The model of VLA-local NGO partnership that was experimented in 2014 will be further expanded to address social injustices, to advance legal empowerment of the poor, and to advocate for creating an enabling environment for CSOs through multiple grants to VLA-CSO partnership and at the structural level, to development of a Law on Association in Viet Nam

actual.comment: 1) 4-very good. Data collection for the Justice Index completed in December, giving voice to more than 13,600 person nationwide. Three law submissions and proposals for law amendments were submitted to the National Assembly with UNDP support, including the Law on Referendum, the revised Law on Administrative Litigation, the revised Law on Temporary Custody and Detention. 2) More than 8,000 people benefited by the VLA legal aid. 3) The partnership model continues to improve - three joint initiatives were granted and contributed to addressing prioritized demand for justice at grass-root level.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1) Number of PR policies streamlined/harmonized/mainstreamed into the regular plans and policy framework of line ministries, following concrete guidelines from the Resolution 80 and its Action Plan 2) Extent to which the program document and guidelines for implementation and management of the harmonized NTP-SPR reflect the application of PR innovative modalities and block grant model (1-No progress: no consideration, 2-In progress: good practices in innovation and block grant model discussed and considered in different policy dialogues, 3-Good progress: policy recommendations taken/integrated in newly issued or revised policy documents), 3) Degree to which empowerment is executed and extent to which multi-dimensional needs of chronic poor people, including poor women, ethnic minority people are met during the implementation of the NTP-SPR (1. No progress: no consideration, 2. In progress: good practices in innovation and block grant model discussed and considered in different policy dialogues, 3. Good progress: policy recommendations taken/integrated in newly issued or revised policy documents),

baseline.comment: 1) 40 poverty reduction policies and programs exist in a fragmented way and sometimes are designed in an ad-hoc manner, though the Resolution 80 already defined directions for streamlining and mainstreaming of poverty reduction policies and harmonizing national poverty reduction program. 2) 1-No progress. Community-based participatory planning and budgeting models available in 28 provinces but not yet institutionalized. 3) 1-No progress. Available tools for poverty monitoring are income based, despite a commitment of Ministry of Labor, Invalids and Social Affairs (MOLISA) on development of a road-map for multi-dimensional poverty and emerging vulnerability monitoring and analysis.

target.comment: 1. Zero policies streamlined, but policy recommendations contributed to national guidelines for policy mainstreaming and streamlining of poverty reduction policies and programs 2) 2-In progress. Block Grant modality is introduced/discussed amongst Ministry of Labor, Invalids and Social Affairs (MOLISA), Committee for Ethnic Minorities Affairs (CEMA), Ministry of Finance (MOF) and Ministry of Planning and Investment (MPI) and innovative approaches in 8 pilot provinces replicated in NTPSPR 3) 2-In progress. Multi-dimensional poverty (MDP) approach in monitoring, targeting and formulating poverty reduction policies is in an advanced stage of institutionalization.

actual.comment: 1. No policies streamlined yet, but key progress was made, specifically: 1.1 Findings and recommendations from UNDP supported 10 policy researches disseminated to government, providing options on the way forward for the poverty reduction policies and NTP-SPR. 1.2 Actions shaped and followed up, as evidenced in the National Assembly's Report and Resolution 176/2014 of the Supreme Oversight on Poverty reduction, the plan for National Assembly Supreme Oversight on Forestation Farms and Ethnic Minorities in 2015, and the government directives and actions via the issuance of 20 policy documents. 2) 3-Good progress. The 'commune ownership' principles reflected in various policy documents, e.g. National Assembly Resolution 176, Government Directives 187, MPI/MOLISA Circular 68. Lessons learnt from livelihood initiatives piloted in 8 provinces (that directly benefit 8,000 men and women from 18 ethnic minority groups) shared to the national policy makers, ensuring the translation of success factors to encourage ethnic minorities’ participation and community empowerment into future PR policy framework and the NTPSPR. 3) 3-Good progress: participatory formulation of the MDP measures achieved. This helped increase consensus among stakeholders on moving toward multidimensional poverty approach, which has been translated into the National Assembly's Resolution 76/2014/QH13 requiring the government to develop a new multidimensional poverty line.

target.comment: 1) 16 national targeted programs harmonized/consolidated into 2 national targeted programs; 3 education policies harmonized/consolidated into one. 2) 2-In progress. NTP- SPR 2016-2020 formulated in a consultative and harmonized process, based on the good practices and innovative models promoting resource integration, community empowerment and enhanced people's participation. 3) 3-Good progress. MDP Master Plan approved by the Prime Minister, with actions to address multidimensional needs of the poor.

actual.comment: 1) 16 targeted programs consolidated into 2 major national targeted programs (NTPs) for new rural development and poverty reduction: (i) National Assembly Resolution 100/2015/QH13 on investment of two NTPs, (ii) a draft policy by Ministry of Education and Training, replacing 3 education support policies. Importantly, UNDP enabled the issuance of the Govt’s MDG accelerated targets and action plan for Ethnic Minority (MAP-EM). The Viet Nam’s MDG acceleration targets is the first in the world attempt to go beyond addressing the unfinished MDGs at the national averages to addressing the unfinished MDGs among specific population groups. This contributed to the recognition of EM groups’ lagging behind national MDG progress as a national priority and directed two major NTPs to focus on the poorest EM communities. 2) 2-in progress. UNDP‘s work led to the adoption (i) by MPI, MOLISA, MARD and CEMA, the harmonization in the design of the NTP-SPR, with focus on improving community ownership as evidenced in the NA Resolution 100 on NTPs, and (ii) by Committee of Ethnic Minority Affairs and 8 provinces, of the social anthropological approaches in policy formulation and practice of participatory planning. These have contributed to (i) improvements in the national poverty reduction program’s identifying needs of the EM people and meeting these needs, (ii) proposal of the ministries for improving people participation and community empowerment toward a self-help and inclusive community development approach in the detail design of the two NTPs 2016-2020 targeting the poorest communities, including of EM people. 3) 3-Good progress. The Government of Viet Nam (GOVN) adopted multi-dimensional poverty (MDP) approach under the Prime Minister’s Decision No.1614/QĐ-Ttg. This MDP Master plan guides the national poverty reduction programming and targeting for 2016-2020. The adoption of MDP recognizes both income and non-income deprivations of the poor people, including ethnic minority poo

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1) Number of accompanying Decrees and legal documents developed and issued to support the promulgation of the Disaster Risk Management Law 2) Number of disaster risk reduction (DRR) and climate change adaptation (CCA) policies, strategies and legislation revised to: - Embrace and keep track of changing dynamics of DRR, CCA and CC impacts; - Integrate gender equity and differing needs of vulnerable groups 3) Improvement of technical and functional capacity of Central Committee for Flood and Storm Control (CCFSC) and provincial stakeholders, measured by: - % completion of capacity building activities planned in the project. - Number of direct beneficiaries of capacity building activities. - The increasing of overall capacity scorecard points (to be indicated in the Capacity Assessment Report by end of 2016). 4) Number of targeted vulnerable communes/wards have CBDRM plan of action developed under the CBDRM Programme 5) Number of “building blocks” for the CBDRM programme approved and disseminated

baseline.comment: 1) Zero. By end of 2011, Version 3 of the Disaster Risk Management (DRM) Law was circulated to Ministries and for public consultation. A first draft of the accompanying Decree was produced 2) Zero. The existing overall disaster risk reduction (DRR) and climate change adaptation (CCA) framework, though comprehensive, not yet reflecting the national, regional and international context and impacts of climate change, neither integrating gender equity and needs of vulnerable groups 3) Overall capacity scorecard of CCFSC was 2.2 points out of 5 points (2013) 4) None. 5) None. “Building blocks” are in the final stage of development, not yet rolled out.

target.comment:
1a) 2-good progress. The DRM Law is well promulgated for implementation guidelines and accompanying Decrees 1b) No specific target in terms of overall capacity scorecard, as the updated survey (post assessment) will not be done until end of 2016. 1c) 100% new/revised DRR and CCA policies/guidance that address all components of DRM and that keep track of the changing dynamics of DRR and CCA and of climate change impacts 1d) 100% of new DRR and CCA policies/guidance take significant account of disaster risk and climate change challenges; integrate issues of gender equality and the differing needs of vulnerable groups
2a) 100 communes/wards that conduct CBDRM activities according to their locally developed plans, under the CBDRM Programme 2b) 2-significant 2c) 3 (out of 7) “building blocks” for the CBDRM programme approved, regularly reviewed and disseminated.

actual.comment:
1a) 3-very good progress. The Law was in full operation, having supported by 01 Decree to guide the overall implementation of the Law and 01 Decree on Provincial Disaster Prevention Fund; Technically, 02 Decisions (i) Disaster risk level and (ii) Communication of DRM in emergencies were also developed and disseminated to provinces to support their decision making processes in the implementation of the DRM Law. 1b) No specific result in terms of overall capacity scorecard, as the capacity assessment will be done by end 2016. Key interim results are: - 424 participants (93 women) in 19 high risk provinces trained on new Law, degrees… - 123 national and local officials (21 women) trained on coastal erosion protection - 45 participants (10 women) from Southern and Central regions benefited from regional technical capacity building. 1c) 100%. All of the 4 revised DRR and CCA policies/guidance address all components of DRM and keep track of the changing dynamics of DRR and CCA and of climate change impacts: - 1 technical guideline on CBDRM implementation - 2 Decisions on CBDRM training and CBDRA process - 1 Decision on CBDRM M&E 1d) 100%. All of the 04 policy guidance on CBDRM above address well the CC, gender and needs/rights of vulnerable groups
2a) 100 communes/wards that conduct CBDRM activities according to their locally developed plans, under the CBDRM Programme 2b) 2-significant. This was achieved through training for all DMC and CCFSC staff on their project management skill and other update on DRM Law and policy regulation. 2c) 3 (out of 7) “building blocks” for the CBDRM programme approved, regularly reviewed and disseminated.

target.comment:
1a) 3-very good progress. Continue to monitor the implementation of the Financial mechanism to implement the DRM Law, particularly the Decree on Disaster Prevention Fund 1b) No specific target in terms of overall capacity scorecard, but continue to build the capacity for CCFSC in term of (i) Damage and Need assessment; (ii) Risk assessment; (iii) Extreme flood and super-storm risk management 1c) 100%. 1d) 100%. Ensure appropriate inclusion of climate change, gender and rights of vulnerable groups in the Action Plan to implement the National Strategy on DRM
2a) At least 250 new communes conducted CBDRM planning 2b) 2- significant. Project will continue to monitor the reform of CCFSC and prepared for an updated survey for CCNDPC/DMC on their specific needs for technical capacity support in 2016. 2c) 01 additional “building block” for the CBDRM programme financing reviewed for future approval in 2016

actual.comment:
1a) 3-very good progress. Initial analysis of CBDRM financing presented at mid-term review, and specific study on sustainable funding strategy for DRM initiated. 1b) No specific result in terms of overall capacity scorecard, but 320 CCFSC staff (34% are women) trained on (i) Damage and Need assessment; (ii) Risk assessment; (iii) Extreme flood and super-storm risk management. 1c) 100%. Draft Action Plan developed in partnership with World Bank addressing all components of DRF and keep track of the changing dynamics of DRR and CCA and of climate change impact. 1d) 100%. Inclusion of climate change, gender and rights of vulnerable groups ensured in the draft Action Plan to implement the National Strategy on DRM.
2a) Estimated 270 communes conducted CBDRM planning with provincial/ NGO/ WB funds. 2b) 2-significant. CCFSC reform monitored and an updated survey on specific needs for technical capacity support well prepared for 2016. 2c) 01 “building block”. Study initiated that will lay the foundation for this ‘building block’ to be finalized for review in 2016.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1) Availability of multi-dimensional poverty (MDP) measures and level of institutionalization of the measures in Ho Chi Minh city (HCMC) 2) Availability of multi-dimensional and in-depth analyses on poverty status for evidence-based and participatory policy making 3) Number of evidence-based and participatory policies developed/revised/improved to address multi-dimensional poor and to ensure equal access to services 4) The availability of new and creative tools to address urban poverty following multi-dimensional approach. 5) The extent to which HCMC’s experience is shared with and applied by other provinces

baseline.comment: 1) Multi-dimensional poverty measures do not exist in Ho Chi Minh city (HCMC). Poverty status is monitored based on a monetary approach 2) There is a lack of multi-dimensional and in-depth analyses on poverty status for evidence-based and participatory policy making 3) Very few evidence-based and participatory policies that address multi-dimensional poverty, despite the fact that HCMC population is still suffering from many deficiencies, such as social security, housing, health care, and education, etc. 4) No tools specifically address urban poverty following multi-dimensional approach. 5) No province being shared or applying the same methodologies and tools, though MOLISA at the central level plans to develop action plans for implementing the Government’s Resolution 80B on poverty reduction following the multi-dimensional approach.

target.comment: 1) - Developed and institutionalized methodologies for measurement of multi-dimensional poverty in Ho Chi Minh city (HCMC); - Reviewed and improved tools and procedures for updating poverty status of HCMC Steering Committee for Poverty Reduction towards multi-dimensional approach. 2) Finalized results of the multi-dimensional poverty pilot survey, which will be used as the basis for analysis of poverty levels according to poverty dimensions, identification of multi-dimensional poverty threshold, selection of poverty dimensions for application, development of policies and models for multi-dimensional poverty reduction in period 2016-2020. 3) Three revised and updated policies for poverty reduction and increase of better-off households for period 2014-2015 following a multi-dimensional and comprehensive approach. 4) Identified innovative poverty reduction tools/models/policies and social assistance for application in Ho Chi Minh city. 5) HCMC’s experience is widely shared through a series of policy discussions and workshops; Methodologies similar to HCMC developed for other cities (with their interest).

actual.comment: 1) Final draft of the MDP measures developed, ready for final pilot on listing and policy making tools; Plan for applying MDP approach in HCMC developed by the Office of Poverty Reduction and proposed to SCPR and PPC 2) 3 research papers on 2013 pilot results, MDP data collection model, and policy framework developed and widely shared 3) Three policies developed/revised following MDP approaches: (i) High consensus and commitment among HCMC leader, agencies in applying MDP in HCMC’s 2016-2020 Poverty Reduction Programme; (ii) HCMC 2014-2015 Poverty Reduction Plan developed in which PPC assigned SCPR to pilot MDP approach in 2 years to provide basis for developing the city’s 2016-2020 Sustainable Poverty Reduction Programme; (iii) MDP Plan proposed by the Office of Poverty Reduction, including creative tools for measuring MDP, identifying prioritized groups, and directing efficient policies. 4) A comprehensive database on MDP for the whole city and 4 pilot districts developed in StatPlanet and widely shared. 5) HCMC’s experience is widely shared through various MDP materials, TV programmes, advocacy, and cooperation with MOLISA, National Assembly and other agencies at central level in the MDP development; 6 provinces officially requested to cooperate with HCMC in MDP progress.

target.comment: 1) MDP measures, data collection procedure for monitoring, listing and targeting finalized and institutionalized 2) Consolidated report on 2013 MDP Pilot completed and shared with wide stakeholders; Research report on actual situation on urbanization and urban management in Viet Nam and in HCMC, suggesting options and actions for improvement 3) Two groups of policy developed based on the MDP approach: (i) Poverty reduction policies reviewed, developed and piloted in a number of HCMC’s localities, tailored to specific needs of prioritized groups, integrated into SEDPs and sectoral plans, and well-coordinated and monitored by different stakeholders; and (ii) HCMC's 2016-2020 Sustainable Poverty Reduction Programme 4) Policy pilots implemented, providing experience and recommendations for scaling up; MDP indicators and non-registered migrants included into VHLSS for MDP monitoring; Prioritized groups for poverty reduction identified 5) HCMC’s MDP progress and experience widely shared and consulted with central and local policy makers, researchers, etc. through various advocacy and media events, workshops for sharing experience, identifying areas for cooperation, planning future roadmap with other provinces

actual.comment: 1) MDP measures, data collection procedure for monitoring, listing and targeting officially approved by HCMC People's Council for application in HCMC's 2016-2020 Sustainable Poverty Reduction Programme 2) Consolidated report on 2013 MDP Pilot, Urban Poverty Report 2012, and 4 working papers on MDP analysis, policy suggestions, and data collection models completed and shared with wide stakeholders; 3) HCMC's 2016-2020 Sustainable Poverty Reduction Programme developed with the official application of MDP approach and method. A relevant detailed policy framework is being developed and tailored to address specific deprivations of prioritized groups, integrated into SEDPs and sectoral plans, and well-coordinated and monitored by different stakeholders. 4) A number of policy interventions and coordination improvements implemented, providing experience and recommendations for developing the detailed policy framework for HCMC's new sustainable poverty reduction programme in 2016-2020; MDP indicators and non-registered migrants included into VHLSS for MDP monitoring; 5 prioritized groups for poverty reduction have been officially identified for relevant supports. 5) A "South-South Exchange Workshop on addressing MDP and improving Service Delivery" co-organized by UNDP Viet Nam (in coordination with UNDP BRH) and HCMC to share and exchange HCMC experience with 6 countries and OPHI. HCMC’s MDP progress and experience also widely shared and consulted with central and local policy makers, researchers, etc. through various advocacy and media events, workshops for sharing experience, identifying areas for cooperation, planning future roadmap with other provinces (Da Nang, Vung Tau, KonTum, etc.).

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1) Compatibility of the revised Statistics Law and under-law documents with official statistical principles (UNSD), with the focus on ensuring (i) collection of objective, reliable and timely data, (ii) users’ transparent access to data 2) Availability and actual operation of new organizational structures, regulations, mechanisms, and tools to serve data sharing (i) within GSO; (ii) among main data producers/providers in the VSS and between those main data producers/providers with GSO; and (iii) with data users. 3) Level of satisfaction of data users related to (i) accessibility; (ii) quality; and (iii) timeliness of statistical data released by GSO. 4) Quality of national accounts data and users’ satisfaction of national accounts data (Scale: 1- poor; 2-relatively good; 3-good; 4-very good) 5) Timeliness and usefulness of information and data to measure progress against objectives, to identify difficulties to be addressed in a timely manner, and to draw lessons in the implementation of VSDS, and its action plans (Scale: 1-poor; ; 2-relatively good; 3-good; 4-very good)

baseline.comment: 1) Legal framework (the Statistics Law 2003 and under-law documents) for statistical activities is not adequate/does not ensure official statistical principles (UNSD) and overlaps, which causes difficulties for implementation; 2) Inefficient organizational structures, lack of regulations/policies/ mechanisms and tools for data sharing, poor compliance of the statistical legislation, lack of sanctions, etc., causing poor implementation of the reporting system between ministries/agencies and GSO/PSOs, insufficient and limited sharing of primary data even among GSO departments, inconsistent data sources, and confusions and reduction of trust by data users. 3) The satisfaction level with disseminated statistical information by data users was at 31.3% in 2008 (GSO’s survey, 2008). 4) 1-poor. The reasons include: Limited knowledge of sectoral and provincial statistical reporting systems of statistical staff in ministries and provinces is still limited; Lack of information needed for the aggregation of National accounts indicators. 5) 1-poor, though a Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) Framework of the implementation of VSDS issued by Ministry of Planning and Investment (GSO).

target.comment: 1) Draft of Revised Statistics Law and Decree is in compatibility with official statistical principles (UNSD), especially in ensuring (i) collection of objective, reliable and timely data, (ii) users’ transparent access to data. 2) Regulations and mechanisms on data sharing developed, such as (i) Regulations on State statistical information dissemination of the Concentrated Statistical System issued by MPI; and (ii) Mechanism for provision and sharing of statistical information among the line ministries developed and issued. 3) Increased level of satisfaction of data users 4) 2-relatively good. This can be achieved through: (i) knowledge on SNA 2008 of statistical staff in local levels improved; (ii) Input-Output table updated providing useful information for policy making 5) 2-relatively good. This can be achieved through enhanced capacity for monitoring and evaluating the implementation of VSDS and its action plans

actual.comment: 1) Law on Statistics and Decree are under revision; Policy on State Statistical Information dissemination issued. 2) Regulations and mechanisms on data sharing developed, including: (i) In the process of developing VSDS 2011-2020, Vision to 2030, a number of mechanisms established and operated quite effectively to coordinate agencies within the VSS and between GSO and development partners, such as an Advisory Group and One Plan mechanism for projects supporting development of VSDS; and (ii) A web-based software for online M&E of VSDS implementation for GSO 3) Level of users’ satisfaction was 31.5%, almost the same as the baseline level of 31.3% 4) 2-relatively good. This was achieved through: (i) the development of a methodology for compilation of GDP at the central level by GSO, as requested by Prime Minister; and (ii) availability of an updated version of the Input-Output tables based on findings of 2013 Input-Output survey 5) 2-relatively good. This was achieved as a result of enhanced capacity for monitoring and evaluating the implementation of VSDS and its action plans through (i) training on VSDS M&E, (ii) an assessment of 2013 M&E implementation, and (iii) the development of an online M&E of VSDS implementation

target.comment: 1) Final draft of Revised Statistics Law and Decree is in compatibility with official statistical principles (UNSD), especially in ensuring (i) collection of objective, reliable and timely data, (ii) users’ transparent access to data. 2) Regulations and mechanisms on data sharing further developed, including: (i) Project on "Improvement of state management of statistical data quality" completed and approved by MPI for implementation; (ii) A strategy for Viet Nam Statistical System’s integration into ASEAN for the period 2016-2020 endorsed by the Prime Minister which is the basis for comprehensive integration in statistics field; and (iii) A web-based software for online M&E of VSDS implementation for ministries and provinces developed and used. 3) Increased level of users’ satisfaction 4) 3-good. This can be achieved through: (i) A roadmap for implementation of GRDP project endorsed by the Prime Minister; and (ii) A macroeconomic analysis based on the updated Input-Output tables 5) 3-good. This can be achieved through a mid-term review of the VSDS implementation

actual.comment: 1) The Statistics Law 2015 approved by the National Assembly in November and launched in December with the integration of National Statistics Indicators for SDGs monitoring and evaluation. A decree on implementation guidance of the Law is being developed. 2) The project on "Improvement of state management of statistical data quality" is being finalized for approval by MPI for implementation; 3) Data not available to measure the achievement of this target 4) 3-good. A roadmap for implementation of GRDP project endorsed by the Prime Minister; A macroeconomic analysis based on the updated Input-Output tables has been completed and widely shared with users. 5) 3-good. The mid-term review of VSDS implementation is being implemented and will be finished by early 2016 to draw lessons learnt, to identify bottlenecks and to suggest sollutions and renovations in implementing the VSDS for the coming half of the whole implementation period 2011-2020.

location.name: Da Nang
location.description: seat of a first-order administrative division

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1.1 Availability of a staff recruitment mechanism based on merit and competencies. Scaling from 0-3, where: 0: mechanism not available, 1: draft mechanism being prepared and shared for consultations, 2: draft mechanism finalized and going through the formal approval process, 3: mechanism approved and implemented. 1.2 Availability of a staff performance appraisal system (integrated into the staff management information system). Scaling from 0-3, where: 0: system not available, 1: draft system being prepared and shared for consultations, 2: draft system finalized and going through the formal approval process, 3: system approved and implemented. 1.3 Number of civil servants using the staff performance appraisal system on regular basis. 1.4 Availability of a mechanism for result-based remuneration for civil servants. Scaling from 0-3, where: 0: mechanism not available, 1: draft mechanism being prepared and shared for consultations, 2: draft mechanism finalized and going through the formal approval process, 3: mechanism approved and implemented. 1.5 Availability of a training programme specialized for different categories of civil servants. Scaling from 0-3, where: 0: training programme not available, 1: draft training programme being prepared and shared for consultations, 2: draft training programme finalized and going through the formal approval process, 3: training programme approved and implemented. 1.6 Availability of a modern staff management information system (including staff recruitment, performance appraisal, training, etc.). Scaling from 0-3, where: 0: system not available, 1: draft system being prepared and shared for consultations, 2: draft system finalized and going through the formal approval process, 3: system approved and implemented. 2.1 Availability of a set of indicators and toolkits for assessment of satisfaction with the quality of public administrative services. Scaling from 0-3, where: 0: indicators and toolkits not available, 1: draft indicator

baseline.comment: 1.1 Rating: 0. Non-existence of a staff recruitment process based on merit and competencies. Current staff recruitment process is not based on competencies but mainly relies on diplomas, and certificates. 1.2 Rating: 0. Non-existence of a result-based staff performance appraisal system. A set of indicators and criteria to assess work performance of civil servants are being developed. 1.3 Zero civil servant use the staff performance appraisal system, which has not been made available at the beginning of the project. 1.4 Rating: 0. Non-existence of a mechanism for result-based remuneration for civil servants. Remuneration policies for civil servants are not based on merits but rather on performance-unrelated diplomas and seniority. 1.5 Rating: 0. Non-existence of a training programme specialized for different categories of civil servants. Civil servant structure is not available, without job description for each position. Education and training provided to civil servants is not based on job positions’ requirements. 1.6 Rating: 0. Non-existence of a modern staff management information system (including staff recruitment, performance appraisal, training, etc.). Current staff management information system needs to be upgraded towards online, and integrated with new modules such as staff recruitment, performance appraisal, training… 2.1 Rating: 0. Non-existence of a specialized and independent unit and standard tools for measuring the quality of public administrative services delivered to citizens and organizations. 2.2 Zero online feedbacks by citizens and organizations on quality of public administrative services delivery.

target.comment: 1.1 Rating: 1. 01 toolkit and guidelines for staff recruitment process developed. 1.2 Rating: 1. 01 set of indicators for result-based staff performance developed. 1.3 The newly-developed set of indicators piloted for civil servants at provincial departments and head of commune people’s committees. 1.4 Rating: 1. 01 draft proposal on mechanism for result-based remuneration for civil servants developed. 1.5 Rating: 1. 01 training curriculum for development of staff structure with job description for each position developed. 1.6 Rating: 1. 02 modules of staff management software developed. 2.1 Rating: 1. 01 set of indicators for assessment of users’ satisfactions on quality of public administrative services developed. 2.2 15,000 feedbacks on public administrative services provided online.

actual.comment: 1.1 Rating: 1. 01 proposal on recruitment procedures (incl. 1 toolkit, guidelines, bank of questionnaires and 1 software application module) developed and ready for installations in all 20 provincial Departments and 7 districts. 1.2 Rating: 1. 02 proposals (02 set of indicators) on performance appraisal for i) employees of public service delivery agencies (PSDA); and ii) chairmen of commune People’s Committees developed 1.3 The newly-developed set of indicators piloted at all provincial departments and used to assess performance of all people’s committees chairperson at commune level. 1.4 Rating: 2. 01 proposal on mechanism for results-based remuneration developed and submitted to the Government (Ministry of Home Affairs, Ministry of Finance, Office of the Government) for approval. 1.5 Rating: 1. 01 training curriculum for development of staff structure with job description for each position. As a result, 14,000 positions has been developed with job description. 1.6 Rating: 2. 03 modules of staff management software developed: staff recruitment, staff performance appraisal and e-cards for 27,987 civil servants. 2.1 Rating: 1. 01 set of indicators for online assessment of users’ satisfactions on quality of public administrative services developed. 2.2 28,360 online feedbacks on public administrative services provided at one-stop-shops.

target.comment: 1.1 Rating: 1. The newly-developed recruitment guidelines piloted in all 20 provincial departments and districts (using software application). 1.2 Rating: 3. The performance appraisal system finalized and submitted to relevant authorities (Ministry of Home Affairs, Office of the Government) for approval of official application. 1.3 100% civil servants of Da Nang use the newly developed performance appraisal system on regular basis. 1.4 Not applicable, as there is no 2015 target for this indicator. 1.5 Rating: 2. 02 training curricula developed by Ministry of Home Affairs (MOHA) for different categories of civil servants reviewed and customized, taking into consideration of Da Nang context. 1.6 Not applicable, as there is no 2015 target for this indicator. 2.1 Rating: 3. 01 set of indicators for online assessment of users’ satisfactions on quality of public administrative services reviewed and revised. Other tools for collecting feedbacks from users developed. 2.2 60,000 online feedbacks on public administrative services provided on one-stop-shops performance. 5,000 direct feedbacks from other channels.

actual.comment: 1.1 Rating: 1. The newly-developed recruitment guidelines piloted in all 20 provincial departments and districts (using software application). 1.2 Rating: 3. The performance appraisal system finalized and submitted to relevant authorities (Ministry of Home Affairs, Office of the Government) for approval of official application. 1.3 100% civil servants of Da Nang use the newly developed performance appraisal system on regular basis. 1.4 Not applicable, as there is no 2015 target for this indicator. 1.5 Rating: 2. 02 training curricula developed by Ministry of Home Affairs (MOHA) for different categories of civil servants reviewed and customized, taking into consideration of Da Nang context. 1.6 Not applicable, as there is no 2015 target for this indicator. 2.1 Rating: 3. 01 set of indicators for online assessment of users’ satisfactions on quality of public administrative services reviewed and revised. Other tools for collecting feedback from users developed. 2.2 48,686 online feedback on public administrative services provided on one-stop-shops performance. 5,000 direct feedback from other channels.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Number of policy dialogues between central and local levels and among localities on PAR issues organized. 2.1 Number of local PAR initiatives in Bac Giang, Can Tho, Da Nang and Ha Tinh supported. 2.2 Number of good practices piloted in 4 localities Bac Giang, Can Tho, Da Nang and Ha Tinh used/replicated by other localities. 2.3 Number of good practices, documents and publications (i.e movie) reflecting lessons drawn from local PAR initiatives. 2.4 Number of national regulations developed/revised, using inputs from 4 local projects.

baseline.comment: 1. Non-existence of regular dialogues between central and local levels and among localities on PAR issues. 2.1 Local PAR initiatives in Bac Giang, Can Tho, Da Nang and Ha Tinh received limited technical support from the Ministry of Home Affairs (MOHA). 2.2 Non-existence of PAR good practices on public human resource reform and public administration service delivery in 4 localities Bac Giang, Can Tho, Da Nang and Ha Tinh. 2.3 Local knowledge and experiences on PAR are not gathered, processed and documented for systematic, wide and continuous circulation. 2.4 Local initiatives on public human resource reform and public administration service delivery are not effectively used by MOHA for national regulations development/revision.

target.comment: 1. 01 policy dialogue between central and local levels and among localities on PAR issues organized. 2.1 02 local PAR initiatives in Bac Giang, Can Tho, Da Nang and Ha Tinh supported. 2.2 01 initiative piloted in one locality used/replicated by other localities. 2.3 03 good practices, reflecting lessons drawn from local PAR initiatives, documented. 2.4 01 proposal provided to MOHA for consideration in development of national regulations on PAR.

actual.comment: 1. 02 policy dialogues between central and local levels and among localities on PAR issues organized. 2.1 07 local PAR initiatives in Bac Giang, Can Tho, Da Nang and Ha Tinh supported. 2.2 01 software application for public human resource management in Da Nang city customized and piloted in Can Tho city. 2.3 03 good practices, reflecting lessons drawn from local PAR initiatives, documented. 01 website developed and used for information sharing among PAR projects. 2.4 01 draft proposal on minimum data managed by provincial public human resource management information system (HRMIS).

target.comment: 1. 03 policy dialogue between central and local levels and among localities on PAR issues organized. 2.1 10 local PAR initiatives in Bac Giang, Can Tho, Da Nang and Ha Tinh supported. 2.2 03 initiative piloted in one locality used/replicated by other localities. 2.3 05 good practices, reflecting lessons drawn from local PAR initiatives, documented. 2.4 02 proposals provided to MOHA for consideration in development of national regulations on PAR.

actual.comment: 1. 03 policy dialogue between central and local levels and among localities on PAR issues organized. 2.1 10 local PAR initiatives in Bac Giang, Can Tho, Da Nang and Ha Tinh supported. 2.2 03 initiative piloted in one locality used/replicated by other localities. 2.3 05 good practices, reflecting lessons drawn from local PAR initiatives, documented. 2.4 02 proposals provided to MOHA for consideration in development of national regulations on PAR.

Lessons from this pilot will inform the design of national features on BDS/IAS later on. 6) 01 proposal. indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1) Number of high quality researches, knowledge products and policy dialogues on issues under national legislative agenda made available by the Institute for Legislative Studies (ILS) for National Assembly committees to support their legislation-making work 2) The extent to which technical inputs produced by the Project are used by National Assembly committees when they review draft legislation (Scale: 0-very little; 1-little; 2-significant; 3-very significant) 3) Number of legislative information exchange events and publications that enhance exchanges on legislative information between Institute for Legislative Studies and National Assembly committees

baseline.comment: 1) Almost no high-quality research, knowledge products by the ILS available to inform the legislation-making process of National Assembly committees. 2) 1-very little. National Assembly committees do not have adequate technical inputs and analysis necessary for their review of draft legislation 3) Very limited number of information exchange events and publications between the Institute for Legislative Studies (as legislative information provider) and National Assembly committees.

target.comment: 1) 4 quality researches and knowledge products provided to National Assembly committees to inform the legislation making of important laws under national legislative agenda 2) 2-significant 3) At least 10 legislative information exchange events and publications

1) At least 4 quality researches and knowledge products provided to National Assembly committees to inform the legislation making of important laws under national legislative agenda such as Law on Referendum, Law on Access to Information, Law on Demonstration, Law on Associations, Law on Custody and Detention, Criminal Code/Criminal Procedural Code, Civil Code and Civil Procedural Code 2) 2-significant 3) At least 8 legislative information exchange events and publications

actual.comment: 1) 5 quality researches and knowledge products provided to National Assembly committees to inform the legislation making of important laws under national legislative agenda such as Law on Referendum, Law on Access to Information, Law on Demonstration, Law on Associations, Law on oversight of the NA and people's councils, Law on participation in international treaties. These are: (i) Study on the current legislation of oversight activities of People’s Council at all level – with recommendations for improvements in line with the new Constitution (ii) Research on legal basis regarding ILS' roles, functions and tasks in providing consultation to MPs to exercise their right to present legislative initiatives (iii) Research on Oversight of National Assembly on the enforcement of international conventions which Vietnam is a member (iv) Research and overall assessment on existing provisions of Law on Oversight Activities of NA and recommendations for improvements (v) Study on “Citizens’ right to participate in state and social management in accordance to Article 28, 2013 Constitution” 2) 2-significant. Research recommendations on Member of Parliament's legislative initiatives were fully taken in the Law on Laws 3) 5 legislative information exchange events and publications and 2 special editions of Legislation Studies Magazine published

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1) Level of awareness and capacity of the Government officers in human rights treaty reporting, specifically in relation to the UPR, and selected human rights treaties (1 - very poor; 2 - relatively good; 3 - good; 4 - very good). 2) The extent to which treaty reporting's process and coordination is improved (1 - very poor; 2 - relatively good; 3 - good; 4 - very good). 3) Number of policy-oriented research commissioned to inform the executive in human rights reporting and policy development.

baseline.comment: 1) 1-very poor. Viet Nam is increasingly engaging with human rights mechanisms but the level of awareness and capacity on HR reporting is very poor. 2) 1-very poor. Coordinated and high quality human rights reporting as well as generating human rights data and information is still a big challenge inhibiting the development and implementation of targeted human rights policies in VN; the UPR process is still relatively new and being improved, guidance is needed on how to effectively compile and present the UPR report; Viet Nam is considering ratification of other core human rights treaties 3) Very few policy-oriented research in human rights. Human rights research is very ad hoc and does not focus on topics that are vital for the development of key government human rights policies; access to research products is still limited mostly to research institutions, uncoordinated and not linked to or providing reference for government agencies.

target.comment: 1) 2-Relatively good awareness and capacity of the Government officers in human rights treaty reporting, specifically in relation to the UPR, CRPD and CAT reporting 2) 2-Relatively good. Institutional capacity of Vietnam’s national human rights protection system is increased (to relatively good level) through promotion of UPR insights and experience to at least 60 people from Ministries, Civil Society Organisations (CSOs) and others. 3) One research on feasibility study for establishment of NHRI (National Human Rights Institute) is conducted to provide policy options for Vietnam.

actual.comment: 1) 2-Relatively good level of awareness and capacity of the Government officers in human rights treaty reporting, specifically in relation to the UPR and CAT reporting is achieved, with evidence gathered from - Three international training workshops on the Convention Against Torture (CAT) with inputs from international CAT experts - Online training course on CRPD is ready for use; Uploaded national human rights websites, including MOFA website with HRs information - Dissemination of translated ASEAN Declaration of human rights among civil society organizations and other agencies - Training and discussion to follow up Viet Nam’s 2014 UPR Review in Geneva. 2) 2-Relatively good. Content and process for generating human rights information relevant for treaty body reports and other human rights mechanism is improved (to relatively good level) - this is seen in the effective GOV coordination in UPR reporting, the increased voice and participation of CSOs in the 2014 UPR cycle. 3) One research on NHRI completed and recommendations sent to relevant authorities for consideration.

target.comment: 1) 3-Good level of awareness and capacity of Government officers to be achieved, through continued support with focus on implementation of UPR Action Plan, and CRPD and CAT reporting. 2) 3-Good level of treaty reporting's process and coordination, through support to establish an inter-ministerial reporting coordination group for data collection and monitoring. 3) One research on CRPD statistical gap to be conducted for recommendations to greater compliance in CRPD reporting.

actual.comment: 1) 3-Good. Increased awareness of policy offers on CAT obligations and their implications to behavior changes and practices. Increased awareness of state officers across Government agencies on UPR commitments and the follow-up Action Plan. 2) 3-Good. CAT and CRPD data gap analysis has started and will be continued in 2016. Primary meeting of an inter-ministerial coordination group for human rights was organized. The UPR Action Plan approved by Prime Minister as results of cross-agency coordination led by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. 3) Research on CRPD statistical gap is commissioned, results will be published in 2016.
